article.headline: Oregon State 76, Oregon 72
article.story: CORVALLIS, Ore. (AP) -- This time, it was Oregon State's big men who dominated in the Civil War. Forwards David Lucas and Nick DeWitz each had 22 points and nine rebounds and Oregon State beat Oregon 76-72 Saturday, avenging an earlier Civil War loss in Eugene. Aaron Brooks had 21 points and Malik Hairston had 20 for the Ducks (11-8, 3-7 Pacific-10), who have lost five straight conference games and now sit alone in ninth place. The Beavers (12-9, 4-6) had been reeling since a 74-64 loss to Oregon Jan. 8, dropping five of six games. "For us, given as sporadic as we've been playing, this is a big one," said Oregon State coach Jay John. Oregon coach Ernie Kent went away from the big lineup he used to outrebound the Beavers by 24 the last time, often playing three guards and rarely pairing big men Ian Crosswhite, Mitch Platt and Ray Schafer. Meanwhile, John went big, starting 6-foot-9, 270-pound Kyle Jeffers on the front line with Lucas and DeWitz The result was a slight 36-33 Oregon rebounding advantage. And 21 turnovers kept the Ducks from capitalizing on big plays. "At the beginning of the game, we had them on the ropes," Brooks said. "We had the ball in our hands and it slipped out. Unfortunately, that's our current problem." Oregon clamped DeWitz and Lucas down in Eugene, and a suffocating zone left the Beavers throwing up errant 3-pointers. Oregon State didn't shot much better this game, just 40 percent from the field and 4-of-20 on 3s. But DeWitz, a junior transfer from Iowa, matched career-highs in scoring and rebounding and Lucas' free-throw shooting down the stretch sealed the Beavers' second-straight home win over Oregon. Both teams had a lot on the line, said Lucas, an All-Pac-10 selection last season. "We both were in the same position and we both needed to win," he said. "We (the Beavers) went out there and did our job." Oregon, which began the season 11-1, is now in danger of missing the eight-team conference tournament. "We realize that we played with more energy today," said guard Jordan Kent, who finished with nine points and eight rebounds. "It's not going to be a one-week turnaround." The Beavers led 34-30 at the half on the strength of DeWitz's 11-point first half. Freshman Bryce Taylor pulled the Ducks into a tie, first converting a three-point play and then burying a 3-pointer to knot the game at 62. But Chris Stephens and David Lucas both made two free throws and DeWitz hit a 3 to give the Beavers a seven-point lead with 1:53 left. Brooks was fouled by Beaver guard Lamar Hurd while shooting a 3 with two seconds left. He made all three of his foul shots, but J.S. Nash hit one of two free throws to put the game out of reach. Stephens had 11 points for Oregon State. The game drew a crowd of 10,312. It was the first time since 1999 that Gill Coliseum has had back-to-back 10,000-plus crowds.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
